title: Lam says never discussed resigning with Beijing
text:
(SOUNDBITE) (English) HONG KONG CHIEF EXECUTIVE, CARRIE LAM, SAYING:

"Your answer does not arise - I have never tendered any resignation to the Central People's Government."

Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam was forced to respond to a Reuters special report on Tuesday (September 3).

The report included leaked audio from a private meeting.

She's heard telling a group of businesspeople she would resign - if she could, and that she's stuck between two masters:

(SOUNDBITE) (English) HONG KONG CHIEF EXECUTIVE, CARRIE LAM, SAYING:

"...for a chief executive to have caused this huge havoc to Hong Kong is unforgivable. It's just unforgivable. If I have a choice, the first thing is to quit, having made a deep apology is to step down.

"The room, the political room for the chief executive who, unfortunately, has to serve two masters by constitution, that is the central people's government and the people of Hong Kong, that political room for maneuvering is very, very, very limited.

"I'll be very honest with you, it would be na�ve for me to paint you a rosy picture, that things will be fine or I have a deadline. But I can assure you that Beijing does not have a deadline. They know this will ripple on."

Lam's resignation is one of the key demands of protesters, who want her gone after she tried to pass a hugely unpopular extradition bill, that would have seen suspects sent to mainland China for trial.

It's since morphed into calls for the people of Hong Kong to be able to choose their own chief executive.

Rolling protests show no sign of losing steam - despite more than a thousand arrests since the outbreak of violence.

On Tuesday, Lam said Beijing still trusts her government to solve this three-month crisis, and that they'd never prevented her from stepping down.

(SOUNDBITE) (English) HONG KONG CHIEF EXECUTIVE, CARRIE LAM, SAYING:

"But if you want to understand, because in a private session, I just attempted to explain that as an individual, given the very difficult circumstances, might be, it was an easy choice to leave. But I told myself repeatedly in the last three months that and I and my team should stay on to help Hong Kong."

China's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office said anyone who wants to achieve universal suffrage in the Chinese-ruled city, will get nowhere and reiterated Beijing's support for the embattled Carrie Lam.
